customData.content: 62-year-old Black American male with a medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, small-cell lung cancer, and a 30-pack-year smoking history (ceased 30 years ago) presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute chest pain. Chest pain started 12 hours prior to the presentation and was described as mid-sternal, pressure-like, and squeezing in nature. The patient rated the pain as 8-9/10 in severity, with radiation to the left arm and jaw. The pain was transiently relieved by nitroglycerin and had no identifiable aggravating factors. Patient experienced shortness of breath (SOB) and occasional diaphoresis. He denied nausea, vomiting, palpitations, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), or leg swelling. A cardiac workup (including an echo/ stress test) was done a year prior at an outside facility due to persistent dyspnea which was unremarkable. The patient reported regular annual physicals.

HPI.summary: 62-year-old male presented to the ED with acute chest pain.

customData.content: Patient visited the ED earlier that day for similar symptoms but was discharged after no acute findings were observed. Blood pressure (BP) of 124/76 mmHg, heart rate (HR) of 64 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99-99% on room air. EKG revealed normal sinus rhythm with a ventricular rate of 84 beats per minute (bpm), T-wave inversion in lead V2, and no ST-segment elevation or depression. Laboratory studies showed a troponin level of 62 ng/L, which increased to 63 ng/L six hours later (reference range: 0-20 ng/L), indicating a stable trend. Patient returned to ED due to persistence of symptoms. Glucose level of 108 mg/dL (reference range: 74-106 mg/dL), total cholesterol of 224 mg/dL (reference range: <200 mg/dL), and LDL cholesterol of 146 mg/dL (reference range: <100 mg/dL). Vital signs: blood pressure of 167/110 mmHg, heart rate of 139 bpm, respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination revealed tachycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.

imaging.finding: normal sinus rhythm with a ventricular rate of 84 beats per minute (bpm), T-wave inversion in lead V2, and no ST-segment elevation or depression

HPI.summary: Patient visited the ED earlier that day for similar symptoms but was discharged after no acute findings were observed. Patient returned to ED due to persistence of symptoms.

customData.content: Respiratory examination unremarkable with clear breath sounds bilaterally. Repeat EKG revealed ST elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4) and reciprocal changes in the inferior leads (II, III, AVF). Cardiology consultation was obtained, an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) protocol was activated, and the patient was transferred emergently to the catheterization laboratory. Coronary angiography revealed extensive thrombus in the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, proximal circumflex artery, and high obtuse marginal (OM) branch.

imaging.finding: extensive thrombus in the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery, proximal circumflex artery, and high obtuse marginal (OM) branch

customData.content: Drug-eluting stents were successfully placed in the LAD and circumflex OM branches. Post-procedure left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) was estimated at 25%, down from 30% to 35% on an echocardiogram (2D echo) performed two weeks earlier. Anterior wall hypokinesis was also observed. Patient stabilized in the intensive care unit (ICU) on a regimen of aspirin, prasugrel, and tirofiban. Goal-directed medical therapy initiated to manage blood pressure. Wearable defibrillator placed for cardiac protection. Patient discharged on apixaban and prasugrel due to suspected hypercoagulable state secondary to malignancy and recent cancer treatments.

imaging.finding: Left ventricular ejection fraction decreased from 30% to 35% to 25%

medications.indication: hypercoagulable state secondary to malignancy and recent cancer treatments

customData.content: Oncological history significant for small-cell lung cancer diagnosis in March 2023, following identification of a left neck mass. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy was revealed. Biopsy confirmed small-cell lung cancer with neuroendocrine differentiation. Initial treatment included cisplatin, etoposide, and durvalumab. Radiation therapy completed in June 202

data.content: Patient's condition progressed from initial presentation with chest pain, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis to ED visit with similar symptoms, discharge after no acute findings, and subsequent return due to persistent symptoms. Initial EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversion in V2. Troponin levels showed a slight increase. Elevated glucose and cholesterol levels were noted. Vital signs worsened, with increased blood pressure and heart rate.

Patient's condition progressed from elevated vitals and slightly elevated troponin to ST elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4) and reciprocal changes in the inferior leads (II, III, AVF) on repeat EKG, leading to cardiology consultation, STEMI protocol activation, and transfer to the catheterization laboratory. Coronary angiography revealed extensive thrombus in the proximal LAD, proximal circumflex artery, and high OM branch.

Patient underwent successful placement of drug-eluting stents in the LAD and circumflex OM branches. Post-procedure LVEF decreased to 25%. Anterior wall hypokinesis was observed. Patient stabilized in the ICU on aspirin, prasugrel, and tirofiban. Goal-directed medical therapy initiated. Wearable defibrillator placed. Patient discharged on apixaban and prasugrel due to suspected hypercoagulable state secondary to malignancy and recent cancer treatments.

Patient's oncological history is reviewed, revealing a small-cell lung cancer diagnosis in March 2023, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, biopsy confirmation of small-cell lung cancer with neuroendocrine differentiation, initial treatment with cisplatin, etoposide, and durvalumab, and radiation therapy completed in June 2023.
